newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BRUGES SKYLINE TAKES SHAPE ON BELGIAN BEACH.
newsitem.headline: BRUGES SKYLINE TAKES SHAPE ON BELGIAN BEACH.

text.p: The skyline of Bruges, self-styled Venice of the north, is taking shape on the Belgian coast. Except this time the mediaeval towers and minarets are made entirely out of sand and water.

More than 50 sand sculptors -- mostly volunteers -- from Denmark, Ireland, the United States, Belgium and the Netherlands, have been labouring for 10 days to convert some 10,000 tonnes of sand into Europe's biggest sandcastle.
The structure, standing nearly 13 metres (42 feet) high and standing 51 metres (163 feet) wide and 38 metres (122 feet) deep, is a monument to disposable art.
"By the time we have finished on Friday we will have taken 10 man years just to sculpt it, and in a month it will have worn away," Dutch project leader Eppo Vogel told Reuters.
"But it is worth it. The enjoyment of creating. The challenge. The enjoyment it gives people. And then there is the memory. That will always be there," he added.

But it is not just any old sand. It is a specially blended cocktail of different river sands imported from the Netherlands which, when soaked and then compressed, take on a consistency not unlike cement -- although far less durable.
"It is disposable art, but I don't mind," said sculptor Jan Selen, a student from the Dutch pottery town of Delft.
"It is really enjoyable doing it. You can make really beautiful things. It is really cool," he enthused.
The structure has to be far more durable than the childhood sandcastles on the beach.

When it opens to the paying public on Friday, coincidentally the Assumption Day holiday, it will have to last a month open to the elements and survive the attention of the 100,000 people expected to come to gape in admiration at the detailed carvings.
Towering above them will be the Bruges skyline, and carved into the slopes around them will be depictions of the 1302 Battle of the Golden Spurs -- the last time the Flemish beat the French at war.
Sand sculpting was invented by American Gerry Kirk of California and moved to the Netherlands about six years ago when a group of enthusiasts set up the European Sand Sculpting Association.
The art form is steadily spreading across Europe and now provides full-time employment all the year round for a handful of experts such as Vogel, and part time enjoyment for many more volunteers.
The sculptures are mainly indoors and for tourism events and fairs. Until the Zeebruges project, the only beach work had been at the Dutch resort of Scheveningen, near The Hague.
The projects are not cheap. The Bruges tourist office is paying 9.7 million francs ($255,000) for its sandcastle.
But for Vogel the next project already beckons. He is off to San Diego after Zeebruges at take part in a project to build a sand sculpture 22 metres (70 feet) high.
